call it as much as evidence yeah exactly i mean i guess you can get to moderate levels you can just provide an explanation and say uh because i i have seen those things on three pictures that's how i come or you really provide a list of evidence and say this is the picture this is yeah that's that's asynchronous then right i met the task was a synchronous yeah i mean you could you could do it in a synchronous thing as well if you have a if you have a system doing it of course if you do that in an interactive way and you have things that that the user and the system doesn't know about, then it is difficult. But at least, I mean, I guess it would be interesting to build a system that also can keep this evidence. So basically that when you provide the answer, you have the things we looked at and say, well is the information i used to to come up with the answer i would like to bring an additional aspect to this discussion because the the grand challenge traditionally was always funded by companies and in a way that they also get some output right and even though i fully agree with all of you that we need interactive challenges i think for the grand challenge at acl multimedia we could also maybe do some subtasks like labeling for example many people in multimedia are working on food recognition so it could be a collaborative annotation task also and then later on from, from that collaborative annotation, we could extract metadata, and later on maybe use it for the interactive challenges as a ground truth, even though it might not be completely correct, of course. But as a challenge, if you put it as a challenge, how do you evaluate it? I mean, the challenge has kind of this competition character. Is that not the hackathon stuff? Yeah, exactly exactly because looking at looking at what came out of that meeting in html media on the first morning it was a health based hackathon that's what they wanted to do and we're naturally going to feed into that if we use this data we don't have to right things we can we can do about this i mean for example all of these things have barcodes on them. Right, right. So you can cross-reference this with the international product database and know exactly what this was. And then you can track how much of this happens to the fresh hook by Apple. How much of this was consumed over what amount of time. And, I mean, essentially it will be difficult to track who actually consumed what but the the methodology would be applicable if you have a smaller group of people for a for your health tracking you can see okay what did I actually eat whether what is my nutritional profile just based on things I've seen this sort of stuff. I think this would be fascinating for hackathons. Yeah, I like that. It would be very difficult for the grand challenge because how do you evaluate this? Because we are not all secretly keeping track and having ground truth. Maybe just one comment to this, becauseVid also does this part-based evaluation, right? Where they evaluate with some manual effort 10% of the submissions and then approximate how much there will be. Yeah, if you do that, for example, with product annotations, I mean, even 10% is a crazy amount of work. So there are some grand challenges if you look at it. The way I kind of participated also in some and the one that we won in New Yorker, Melange, that was 10 years ago with Monza. That one was bought by IBM and because they were based in New York, you know, like they wanted to really... This is the definition of Grand Challenge, we wanna show in New York, using all this wealth of social media data, from different perspectives. So, competing teams had totally different solutions, very interesting, somebody focused on the fashion of the city, you know, like, city of fashion. Right. Recommender systems, location recommender systems, and so on and so on. So, when speaking about Grand Challenges, they have also tradition of these open-ended tasks. So, in that sense, what we kind of discussed now as a hackathon could also fit Grand Challenge. But there the checking wasn't on individual items whether they're correct or not. It was really on the overall look and feel of the thing. But this is the more you have a jury that looks at this sort of stuff and they... The look and the feel of the thing is more than... They essentially grade the creativity and the quality of the output and... Presentation also during the conference. Yeah, I mean this is also something that would be interesting to do. but I guess this would be two tracks. description:
The provided image shows a room that appears to be a living or dining area. There are people present, but their activities are not clearly discernible. However, the overall setting suggests a social gathering or a relaxed atmosphere. Based on the visual cues, the most fitting classification would be **Leisure Activities**. 

If there were more context or clearer indicators of specific actions, a more precise classification might be possible.

He carried his own low temperature always about with him. He iced his office in the dog days, and didn't thot one degree at Christmas. Externally heat and cold had little influence on Scrooge. No warmth could warm, no wintry weather chill him. No wind that blew was bitterer than he. No falling snow was more intent upon its purpose. No pelting rain less open to entreaty. Foul weather didn't know where to have him. The heaviest rain and snow and hail and sleet could boast of the advantage of him only in one respect. They often came down handsomely and Scrooge never did.

It's the very thing he liked, to edge his way along the crowded paths of life, warning all human sympathy to keep his distance, was what the knowing ones called nuts to Scrooge. Once upon a time, of all the good days in the year, year on Christmas Eve old Scrooge sat busy in his counting house. It was a cold bleak biting weather foggy with all and he could hear the people in the court outside go wheezing up and down beating their hands upon their breasts and stamping their feet upon the pavement stones to warm them. The city clocks had only just gone three, and it was quite dark already. It had not been light all day, and the candles were flaring in the windows of the neighbouring offices like ruddy smears upon the palpable brown air. The fog came pouring in at every chink and keyhole, and was so dense without that, although the court was... Okay, that's so complicated. The fog came pouring in at every chink and keyhole, and was so dense without that, Although the court was a that's so complicated the fog came pouring in at every chink and keyhole and was so dense without that although the court was of the narrowest the houses opposite were mere phantoms to see the dingy cloud come drooping down obscuring everything one might have thought that nature lived hard by and was brewing on a large scale the door of scrooge's's county house was open so that he could keep an eye on his clerk, who in a dismal little cell beyond, a sort of tank was copying letters. Scrooge had a very small fire but the clerk's fire was so very much smaller that it looked like just one coal. But he couldn't replenish it for Scrooge kept the coal box in his own room and so surely as the clerk came in with the shovel, the master predicted that it would be necessary for them to part. Wherefore the clerk put on his white comforter, he tried to warm himself at the candle, in which effort, not being a man of strong imagination, he failed.

Halted, he peered down the dark winding stairs and called up coarsely, Come up, Kinch. Come up, you fearful Jesuit. Solemnly, he came forward and mounted the round gunrest. He faced about and blessed gravely Trice, the tower, the surrounding country, and the awakening mountains. Then, catching sight of Stephen de Dallas, he bent towards him and made rapid crosses in the air gurgling his throat and shaking his head stephen didalis displeased and sleepy leaned his arms on the top of the staircase and looked coldly at the shaking gurgling face that blessed him equine in his length and at the light on tonsured hair gained and hued like pale oak book mulligan peeped an instant under the mirror then covered the bowl smartly back to barracks he said sternly he added in a preacher's tone for this our dearly beloved is the genuine christine body and soul and blood and nouns slow music please shut your eyes

description:
**Leisure Activities**

The provided images show a man standing in a living room, wearing what appears to be a headlamp or camera. **Classification:** Meeting

**Reasoning:** The image depicts individuals gathered around a table, actively engaged with documents and appearing to be in a discussion. While some elements of leisure might be present (e.g., the relaxed setting), the primary activity appears to be a structured interaction involving shared information.

description:
The segment can be classified as **Playing Games**.

Here's why:

* **Buzzers:** The presence of multiple buzzers on the table strongly suggests a game is being played. These are commonly used in trivia or quiz games.
* **Papers:** The papers in the foreground likely contain game questions or instructions.
* **Group Interaction:** The individuals are gathered around a table, engaged with each other and the game components, indicating a shared activity.
* **Atmosphere:** The overall scene suggests a social gathering focused on an interactive activity.
